stories.title: Show HN: I'm making a site to find the best essential products

stories.text:
Hello to all the HN community! It's Nik here, I founded WeLoveNoCode (welovenocode.com), a platform that connects people with the best no-code developers to build their software and apps without a single line of code. All that is based on a monthly subscription.

My startup just raised $1M in funding and we reached a monthly recurring revenue of $170k+ within less than a year. I have learned a lot from other makers here, So I decided to also share my experience about building a startup that is growing at rocket speed. I hope this helps other entrepreneurs (and if you are looking to join a fast-growth startup, I’m hiring).

So, how did we achieve this kind of growth in a short time? I drafted some important lessons I learned and would like to share them with you: - Start with Satisfying your Customers - Educate the market. - An MVP tells you what your customer really wants - Find a model that works - Be very clear with your value prop - Approach Marketing with a growth mindset - Fundraising is hard: You should see things from an investor's perspective. - VC money is not the only way.

Now, let's dive deeper in comments:
stories.title: Lessons learned after achieving $170k MRR and raising $1M in funding
Bernoulli's Fallacy and the Crisis of Modern Science, with Aubrey Clayton
Chris Balding on the Difference Between the DC Narrative on China and Reality
Mozilla Is Shutting Down Its Password Management App
Workers in Vietnam lived inside factories to keep Samsung’s products on shelves
This webcomic made it okay to be sad online. Then its artist vanished

stories.text: I am an experienced Java engineer (5+ years). I know Java and JVM well enough to do my job that was usually around building microservices/apis etc, I know theoretical stuff well enough to pass core java interviews for senior positions. However, I am applying for a position that requires a lot more than that, it's to do with finance/HFT and they will be asking questions around lower level java I assume. I don't have a spec of what they might ask, I assume stuff around JMH, concurrency and JVM tuning, but maybe anyone know more and can point to the learning resources?
stories.title: Ask HN: How best to prepare for Java performance interviews?
